Moving into the 1980s, the network coverage diversified with CBC showcasing play-by-play announcers like Bob Cole, Danny Gallivan, Jim Robson, and Don Wittman, alongside color commentators including Howie Meeker, John Davidson, Mickey Redmond, and Dick Irvin, Jr. TSN also emerged as a broadcaster, featuring John Wells as a play-by-play announcer in 1986. Transitioning to the 1990s, CBC maintained a consistent lineup with Bob Cole handling play-by-play, Harry Neale as the color commentator, and Ron MacLean as the studio host from 1994 to 1999. Earlier in the early 1990s, TSN took the lead with Jim Hughson, Gary Green, and John Wells in their respective roles. However, the 1995 NHL All-Star Game was canceled due to the 1994-95 NHL lockout, disrupting the broadcast schedule. This era marked a shift from TSN to CBC as the primary networks for NHL All-Star Game coverage, showcasing a stable roster of personnel in key broadcasting positions across the years, reflecting the evolution and diversity in network coverage for NHL All-Star Game broadcasters from the 1960s to the 1990s.
